* If @reference is neither an array nor a reference nor a range, ROWS returns #VALUE! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TRANSPOSE function returns the transpose of the input @matrix.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VLOOKUP function finds the row in range that has a first column similar to @value. If @approximate is not true it finds the row with an exact equivilance. If @approximate is true, then the values must be sorted in order of ascending value for correct function; in this case it finds the row with value less than @value. It returns the value in the row found at a 1-based offset in @column columns into the @range. @as_index returns the 0-based offset that matched rather than the value.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ABS implements the Absolute Value function: the result is to drop the negative sign (if present). This can be done for integers and floating point numbers.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ACOS function calculates the arc cosine of @x; that is the value whose cosine is @x.
* The value it returns is in radians.
* If @x falls outside the range -1 to 1, ACOS returns the #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ACOSH function calculates the inverse hyperbolic cosine of @x; that is the value whose hyperbolic cosine is @x.
* If @x is less than 1.0, ACOSH() returns the #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ASIN function calculates the arc sine of @x; that is the value whose sine is @x.
* If @x falls outside the range -1 to 1, ASIN returns the #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ASINH function calculates the inverse hyperbolic sine of @x; that is the value whose hyperbolic sine is @x.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: ASIN, ACOSH, SIN, COS, DEGREES, RADIANS.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ATAN function calculates the arc tangent of @x; that is the value whose tangent is @x.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ATAN2 function calculates the arc tangent of the two variables @b1 and @b2. It is similar to calculating the arc tangent of @b2 / @b1, except that the signs of both arguments are used to determine the quadrant of the result.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: ATAN, ATANH, COS, SIN, DEGREES, RADIANS.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ATANH function calculates the inverse hyperbolic tangent of @x; that is the value whose hyperbolic tangent is @x.
* If the absolute value of @x is greater than 1.0, ATANH returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: ATAN, TAN, SIN, COS, DEGREES, RADIANS.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BETA function returns the value of the mathematic beta function extended to all real numbers except 0 and negative integers.
* If @a or @b are 0 or negative integers, BETA returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BETALN function returns the natural logarithm of the absolute value of the beta function.
* If @a or @b are non-positive integers, BETALN returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CEIL function rounds @x up to the next nearest integer.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CEILING function rounds @x up to the nearest multiple of @significance.
* If @x or @significance is non-numeric CEILING returns #VALUE! error.
* If @x and @significance have different signs CEILING returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COMBIN computes the number of combinations.
* Performing this function on a non-integer or a negative number returns #NUM! error.
* If @n is less than @k COMBIN returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COS function returns the cosine of @x, where @x is given in radians.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: COSH, SIN, SINH, TAN, TANH, RADIANS, DEGREES.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COSH function returns the hyperbolic cosine of @x, which is defined mathematically as

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: COS, SIN, SINH, TAN, TANH, RADIANS, DEGREES, EXP.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COUNTIF function counts the number of cells in the given @range that meet the given @criteria.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 23, 27, 28, 33, and 39. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DEGREES computes the number of degrees equivalent to @x radians.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: EVEN function returns the number rounded up to the nearest even integer.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: EXP computes the value of e (the base of natural logarithmns) raised to the power of @x.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FACT computes the factorial of @x. ie, @x!

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FACTDOUBLE function returns the double factorial of a @number, i.e., x!!.
* If @number is not an integer, it is truncated.
* If @number is negative FACTDOUBLE returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: * If @number is not an integer, it is truncated.
* If @number is negative or zero FIB returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FLOOR function rounds @x down to the next nearest multiple of @significance.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: G_PRODUCT returns the product of all the values and cells referenced in the argument list.
* Empty cells are ignored and the empty product is 1.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: GCD returns the greatest common divisor of given numbers.
* If any of the arguments is less than zero, GCD returns #NUM! error.
* If any of the arguments is non-integer, it is truncated.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: INT function returns the largest integer that is not bigger than its argument.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LCM returns the least common multiple of integers. The least common multiple is the smallest positive number that is a multiple of all integer arguments given.
* If any of the arguments is less than one, LCM returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LN returns the natural logarithm of @x.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOG computes the logarithm of @x in the given base @base. If no @base is given LOG returns the logarithm in base 10. @base must be > 0. and cannot equal 1.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOG10 computes the base-10 logarithm of @x.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOG2 computes the base-2 logarithm of @x.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MDETERM function returns the determinant of a given matrix.
* If the @matrix does not contain equal number of columns and rows, MDETERM returns #VALUE! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that A1, ..., A4 contain numbers 2, 3, 7, and 3, B1, ..., B4 4, 2, 4, and 1, C1, ..., C4 9, 4, 3, and 2, and D1, ..., D4 7, 3, 6, and 5. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MINVERSE function returns the inverse matrix of @matrix.
* If @matrix cannot be inverted, MINVERSE returns #NUM! error.
* If @matrix does not contain equal number of columns and rows, MINVERSE returns #VALUE! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MMULT function returns the matrix product of two arrays. The result is an array with the same number of rows as @array1 and the same number of columns as @array2.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MOD function returns the remainder when @divisor is divided into @number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MROUND function rounds a given number to the desired multiple.
@number is the number you want rounded and @multiple is the the multiple to which you want to round the number.
* If @number and @multiple have different sign, MROUND returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MULTINOMIAL returns the ratio of the factorial of a sum of values to the product of factorials.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ODD function returns the @number rounded up to the nearest odd integer.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PI functions returns the value of pi.
* This function is called with no arguments.
* This function is Excel compatible, except that it returns pi with a better precision.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: POWER returns the value of @x raised to the power @y.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PRODUCT returns the product of all the values and cells referenced in the argument list.
* This function is Excel compatible. In particular, this means that if all cells are empty, the result will be 0.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: QUOTIENT function returns the integer portion of a division. @numerator is the divided number and @denumerator is the divisor.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RADIANS computes the number of radians equivalent to @x degrees.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ROMAN function returns an arabic number in the roman numeral style, as text. @number is the number you want to convert and @type is the type of roman numeral you want.
* If @type is 0 or it is omitted, ROMAN returns classic roman numbers.
* Type 1 is more concise than classic type, type 2 is more concise than type 1, and type 3 is more concise than type 2. Type 4 is simplified type.
* If @number is negative or greater than 3999, ROMAN returns #VALUE! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ROUND function rounds a given number.
@number is the number you want rounded and @digits is the number of digits to which you want to round that number.
* If @digits is greater than zero, @number is rounded to the given number of digits.
* If @digits is zero or omitted, @number is rounded to the nearest integer.
* If @digits is less than zero, @number is rounded to the left of the decimal point.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ROUNDDOWN function rounds a given @number down. @number is the number you want rounded down and @digits is the number of digits to which you want to round that number.
* If @digits is greater than zero, @number is rounded down to the given number of digits.
* If @digits is zero or omitted, @number is rounded down to the nearest integer.
* If @digits is less than zero, @number is rounded down to the left of the decimal point.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ROUNDUP function rounds a given number up.
@number is the number you want rounded up and @digits is the number of digits to which you want to round that number.
* If @digits is greater than zero, @number is rounded up to the given number of digits.
* If @digits is zero or omitted, @number is rounded up to the nearest integer.
* If @digits is less than zero, @number is rounded up to the left of the decimal point.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SERIESSUM function returns the sum of a power series. @x is the base of the power series, @n is the initial power to raise @x, @m is the increment to the power for each term in the series, and @coefficients is the coefficents by which each successive power of @x is multiplied.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 1.23, 2.32, 2.98, 3.42, and 4.33. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SIGN function returns 1 if the @number is positive, zero if the @number is 0, and -1 if the @number is negative.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SIN function returns the sine of @x, where @x is given in radians.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: COS, COSH, SINH, TAN, TANH, RADIANS, DEGREES.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SINH function returns the hyperbolic sine of @x, which is defined mathematically as

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: SIN, COS, COSH, TAN, TANH, DEGREES, RADIANS, EXP.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SQRT function returns the square root of @x.
* If @x is negative, SQRT returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SQRTPI function returns the square root of a @number multiplied by pi.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SUM computes the sum of all the values and cells referenced in the argument list.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11, 15, 17, 21, and 43. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SUMA computes the sum of all the values and cells referenced in the argument list. Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1).

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11, 15, 17, 21, and 43. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SUMIF function sums the values in the given @range that meet the given @criteria. If @actual_range is given, SUMIF sums the values in the @actual_range whose corresponding components in @range meet the given @criteria.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 23, 27, 28, 33, and 39. Then
In addition, if the cells B1, B2, ..., B5 hold numbers 5, 3, 2, 6, and 7 then:

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SUMPRODUCT function multiplies corresponding data entries in the given arrays or ranges, and then returns the sum of those products. If an array entry is not numeric, the value zero is used instead.
* If arrays or range arguments do not have the same dimensions, SUMPRODUCT returns #VALUE! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11, 15, 17, 21, and 43 and the cells B1, B2, ..., B5 hold numbers 13, 22, 31, 33, and 39. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SUMSQ returns the sum of the squares of all the values and cells referenced in the argument list.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11, 15, 17, 21, and 43. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SUMX2MY2 function returns the sum of the difference of squares of corresponding values in two arrays. @array1 is the first array or range of data points and @array2 is the second array or range of data points. The equation of SUMX2MY2 is SUM (x^2-y^2).
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.
* If @array1 and @array2 have different number of data points, SUMX2MY2 returns #N/A error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11, 15, 17, 21, and 43 and the cells B1, B2, ..., B5 hold numbers 13, 22, 31, 33, and 39. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SUMX2PY2 function returns the sum of the sum of squares of corresponding values in two arrays. @array1 is the first array or range of data points and @array2 is the second array or range of data points. The equation of SUMX2PY2 is SUM (x^2+y^2).
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.
* If @array1 and @array2 have different number of data points, SUMX2PY2 returns #N/A error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11, 15, 17, 21, and 43 and the cells B1, B2, ..., B5 hold numbers 13, 22, 31, 33, and 39. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SUMXMY2 function returns the sum of squares of differences of corresponding values in two arrays. @array1 is the first array or range of data points and @array2 is the second array or range of data points. The equation of SUMXMY2 is SUM (x-y)^2.
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.
* If @array1 and @array2 have different number of data points, SUMXMY2 returns #N/A error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11, 15, 17, 21, and 43 and the cells B1, B2, ..., B5 hold numbers 13, 22, 31, 33, and 39. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TAN function returns the tangent of @x, where @x is given in radians.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: TANH, COS, COSH, SIN, SINH, DEGREES, RADIANS.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TANH function returns the hyperbolic tangent of @x, which is defined mathematically as

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: TAN, SIN, SINH, COS, COSH, DEGREES, RADIANS.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TRUNC function returns the value of @number truncated to the number of digits specified.
* If @digits is omitted then @digits defaults to zero.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ISPRIME function returns TRUE if @i is prime and FALSE otherwise.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NT_D function calculates the number of divisors of @n.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: 0 if @n is divisible by the square of a prime .
-1 if @n has an odd number of different prime factors .
1 if @n has an even number of different prime factors .

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NT_PHI function calculates the number of integers less than or equal to @n that are relatively prime to @n.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NT_PI function returns the number of primes less than or equal to @n.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NT_SIGMA function calculates the sum of the divisors of @n.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RAND returns a random number between zero and one.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: RAND() returns a random number greater than zero but less than one.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDBERNOULLI returns a Bernoulli-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDBETA returns a Beta-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDBETWEEN function returns a random integer number between and including @bottom and @top.
* If @bottom or @top is non-integer, they are truncated.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDBINOM returns a binomially-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDCAUCHY returns a cauchy-distributed random number with scale parameter a. The Cauchy distribution is also known as the Lorentz distribution.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDCHISQ returns a Chi-Square-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDDISCRETE returns one of the values in the @val_range. The probablilites for each value are given in the @prob_range.
* If @prob_range is omitted, the uniform discrete distribution is assumed.
* If the sum of all values in @prob_range is other than one, RANDDISCRETE returns #NUM! error.
* If @val_range and @prob_range are not the same size, RANDDISCRETE returns #NUM! error.
* If @val_range or @prob_range is not a range, RANDDISCRETE returns #VALUE! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: RANDDISCRETE(A1:A6) returns one of the values in the range A1:A6.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDEXP returns a exponentially-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDEXPPOW returns a random variate from the exponential power distribution with scale parameter @a and exponent @b. The distribution is,
p(x) dx = {1 over 2 a Gamma(1+1/b)} exp(-|x/a|^b) dx, for x >= 0.
* For @b = 1 this reduces to the Laplace distribution.
* For @b = 2 it has the same form as a gaussian distribution with sigma = a/sqrt(2).

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDFDIST returns a F-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDGAMMA returns a Gamma-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDGAUSSIAN returns a gaussian-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDGAUSSIANTAIL returns a random variates from the upper tail of a Gaussian distribution with standard deviation @sigma. The values returned are larger than the lower limit @a, which must be positive. The method is based on Marsaglia's famous rectangle-wedge-tail algorithm (Ann Math Stat 32, 894-899 (1961)), with this aspect explained in Knuth, v2, 3rd ed, p139, 586 (exercise 11).
The probability distribution for Gaussian tail random variates is,
p(x) dx = {1 over N(a;sigma)} exp (- x^2/(2 sigma^2)) dx,
for x > a where N(a;sigma) is the normalization constant, N(a;sigma) = (1/2) erfc(a / sqrt(2 sigma^2)).

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDGEOM returns a geometric-distributed random number. The number of independent trials with probability @p until the first success. The probability distribution for geometric variates is,

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDGUMBEL returns a Type I or Type II Gumbel-distributed random number. @type is either 1 or 2 and specifies the type of the distribution (Type I or Type II).
* If @type is neither 1 nor 2, RANDGUMBEL returns #NUM! error.
* If @type is omitted, Type I is assumed.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDHYPERG returns a hypergeometric-distributed random number. The probability distribution for hypergeometric random variates is,
The domain of k is max(0,t-n_2), ..., max(t,n_1).

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDLANDAU returns a random variate from the Landau distribution. The probability distribution for Landau random variates is defined analytically by the complex integral,
p(x) = (1/(2 pi i)) int_{c-i infty}^{c+i infty} ds exp(s log(s) + x s).
For numerical purposes it is more convenient to use the following equivalent form of the integral,
p(x) = (1/pi) int_0^ infty dt exp(-t log(t) - x t) sin(pi t).

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDLAPLACE returns a Laplace-distributed random number. Laplace distribution is also known as two-sided exponential probability distribution.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDLEVY returns a Levy-distributed random number. If @beta is omitted, it is assumed to be 0.
* For @alpha = 1, @beta=0, we get the Lorentz distribution.
* For @alpha = 2, @beta=0, we get the Gaussian distribution.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDLOG returns a logarithmic-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDLOGISTIC returns a logistic-distributed random number. The distribution function is,
p(x) dx = { exp(-x/a) over a (1 + exp(-x/a))^2 } dx for -infty < x < +infty.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDLOGNORM returns a lognormal-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDNEGBINOM returns a negative binomially-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDPARETO returns a Pareto-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDPOISSON returns a poisson-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDRAYLEIGH returns a Rayleigh-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDRAYLEIGHTAIL returns a random variate from the tail of the Rayleigh distribution with scale parameter sigma and a lower limit of a. The distribution is,
p(x) dx = {x over sigma^2} exp ((a^2 - x^2) /(2 sigma^2)) dx,

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDTDIST returns a T-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDUNIFORM returns a random variate from the uniform (flat) distribution from a to b. The distribution is,
* If a <= x < b and 0 otherwise.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: RANDUNIFORM(1.4,4.2) returns a random number greater than or equal to 1.4 but less than 4.2.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANDWEIBULL returns a Weibull-distributed random number.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SIMTABLE returns one of the values in the given argument list depending on the round number of the simulation tool. When the simulation tool is not activated, SIMTABLE returns @d1.

With the simulation tool and the SIMTABLE function you can test given decision variables. Each SIMTABLE function contains the possible values of a simulation variable. In most valid simulation models you should have the same number of values @dN for all decision variables. If the simulation is run more rounds than there are values defined, SIMTABLE returns #N/A! error (e.g. if A1 contains `=SIMTABLE(1)' and A2 `=SIMTABLE(1,2)', A1 yields #N/A! error on the second round).

The successive use of the simulation tool also requires that you give to the tool at least one input variable having RAND() or any other RAND<distribution name>() function in it. On each round, the simulation tool iterates for thegiven number of rounds over all the input variables to reevaluate them. On each iteration, the values of the output variables are stored, and when the round is completed, descriptive statistical information is created according to the values.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: SIMTABLE(TRUE,FALSE) returns TRUE on the first simulation round and FALSE on the second round.
SIMTABLE(223,225,227,229) returns 227 on the simulation round #3.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: AVEDEV returns the average of the absolute deviations of a data set from their mean.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: AVERAGE computes the average of all the values and cells referenced in the argument list. This is equivalent to the sum of the arguments divided by the count of the arguments.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: AVERAGEA returns the average of the given arguments. Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers and strings 11.4, 17.3, "missing", 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BERNOULLI returns the probability p(k) of obtaining @k from a Bernoulli distribution with probability parameter @p.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BETADIST function returns the cumulative beta distribution. @a is the optional lower bound of @x and @b is the optional upper bound of @x.
* If @a is not given, BETADIST uses 0.
* If @b is not given, BETADIST uses 1.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BETAINV function returns the inverse of cumulative beta distribution. @a is the optional lower bound of @x and @b is the optinal upper bound of @x.
* If @a is not given, BETAINV uses 0.
* If @b is not given, BETAINV uses 1.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: BINOMDIST function returns the binomial distribution. @n is the number of successes, @trials is the total number of independent trials, @p is the probability of success in trials, and @cumulative describes whether to return the sum of the binomial function from 0 to @n.
* If @n or @trials are non-integer they are truncated.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CAUCHY returns the Cauchy distribution with scale parameter @a. If @cum is TRUE, CAUCHY returns the cumulative distribution.
* If @cum != TRUE and @cum != FALSE CAUCHY returns #VALUE! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CHIDIST function returns the one-tailed probability of the chi-squared distribution. @dof is the number of degrees of freedom.
* If @dof is non-integer it is truncated.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CHIINV function returns the inverse of the one-tailed probability of the chi-squared distribution.
* If @p < 0 or @p > 1 or @dof < 1 CHIINV returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CHITEST function returns the test for independence of chi-squared distribution.
@actual_range is a range that contains the observed data points. @theoretical_range is a range that contains the expected values of the data points.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CONFIDENCE function returns the confidence interval for a mean. @x is the significance level, @stddev is the population standard deviation, and @size is the size of the sample.
* If @size is non-integer it is truncated.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CORREL returns the correlation coefficient of two data sets.
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.

refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1, and the cells B1, B2, ... B5 23.2, 25.8, 29.9, 33.5, and 42.7. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COUNT returns the total number of integer or floating point arguments passed.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COUNTA returns the number of arguments passed not including empty cells.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers and strings 11.4, "missing", "missing", 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: AVERAGE, COUNT, DCOUNT, DCOUNTA, PRODUCT, SUM.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: COVAR returns the covariance of two data sets.
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1, and the cells B1, B2, ... B5 23.2, 25.8, 29.9, 33.5, and 42.7. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CRITBINOM function returns the smallest value for which the cumulative is greater than or equal to a given value. @n is the number of trials, @p is the probability of success in trials, and @alpha is the criterion value.
* If @trials is a non-integer it is truncated.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CRONBACH returns Cronbach's alpha for the given cases.
@ref1 is a data set, @ref2 the second data set, etc..

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: DEVSQ returns the sum of squares of deviations of a data set from the sample mean.
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: EXPONDIST function returns the exponential distribution. If the @cumulative boolean is false it will return:
* If @x < 0 or @y <= 0 this will return an error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: EXPPOWDIST returns the probability density p(x) at @x for Exponential Power distribution with scale parameter @a and exponent @b.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FDIST function returns the F probability distribution. @dof1 is the numerator degrees of freedom and @dof2 is the denominator degrees of freedom.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FINV function returns the inverse of the F probability distribution.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FISHER function returns the Fisher transformation at @x.
* If @x is not a number, FISHER returns #VALUE! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FISHERINV function returns the inverse of the Fisher transformation at @x.
* If @x is non-number FISHERINV returns #VALUE! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FORECAST function estimates a future value according to existing values using simple linear regression. The estimated future value is a y-value for a given x-value (@x).
* If @known_x or @known_y contains no data entries or different number of data entries, FORECAST returns #N/A error.
* If the variance of the @known_x is zero, FORECAST returns #DIV/0 error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1, and the cells B1, B2, ... B5 23.2, 25.8, 29.9, 33.5, and 42.7. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FREQUENCY function counts how often given values occur within a range of values. The results are given as an array.

@data_array is a data array for which you want to count the frequencies. @bin_array is an array containing the intervals into which you want to group the values in data_array. If the @bin_array is empty, FREQUENCY returns the number of data points in @data_array.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FTEST function returns the two-tailed probability that the variances in the given two data sets are not significantly different.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1, and the cells B1, B2, ... B5 23.2, 25.8, 29.9, 33.5, and 42.7. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: GAMMADIST function returns the gamma distribution. If @cum is TRUE, GAMMADIST returns the incomplete gamma function, otherwise it returns the probability mass function.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: GAMMAINV function returns the inverse of the cumulative gamma distribution.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: GAMMALN function returns the natural logarithm of the gamma function.
* If @x is non-number then GAMMALN returns #VALUE! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: GEOMDIST returns the probability p(k) of obtaining @k from a geometric distribution with probability parameter @p.
* If @cum != TRUE and @cum != FALSE GEOMDIST returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: GEOMEAN returns the geometric mean of the given arguments. This is equal to the Nth root of the product of the terms.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: GROWTH function applies the ``least squares'' method to fit an exponential curve to your data and predicts the exponential growth by using this curve.
GROWTH returns an array having one column and a row for each data point in @new_x.
* If @known_x's is omitted, an array {1, 2, 3, ...} is used.
* If @new_x's is omitted, it is assumed to be the same as @known_x's.
* If @known_y's and @known_x's have unequal number of data points, GROWTH returns #NUM! error.
* If @const is FALSE, the line will be forced to go through the origin, i.e., b will be zero. The default is TRUE.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: HARMEAN returns the harmonic mean of the N data points (that is, N divided by the sum of the inverses of the data points).

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: HYPGEOMDIST function returns the hypergeometric distribution. @x is the number of successes in the sample, @n is the number of trials, @M is the number of successes overall, and @N is thepopulation size.
* If @x,@n,@M or @N is a non-integer it is truncated.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: INTERCEPT function calculates the point where the linear regression line intersects the y-axis.
* If @known_x or @known_y contains no data entries or different number of data entries, INTERCEPT returns #N/A error.
* If the variance of the @known_x is zero, INTERCEPT returns #DIV/0 error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1, and the cells B1, B2, ... B5 23.2, 25.8, 29.9, 33.5, and 42.7. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: KURT returns an unbiased estimate of the kurtosis of a data set.
Note, that this is only meaningful if the underlying distribution really has a fourth moment. The kurtosis is offset by three such that a normal distribution will have zero kurtosis.
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.
* If fewer than four numbers are given or all of them are equal KURT returns #DIV/0! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: KURTP returns the population kurtosis of a data set.
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.
* If fewer than two numbers are given or all of them are equal KURTP returns #DIV/0! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LANDAU returns the probability density p(x) at @x for the Landau distribution using an approximation method.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LAPLACE returns the probability density p(x) at @x for Laplace distribution with mean @a.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LARGE returns the k-th largest value in a data set.
* If data set is empty LARGE returns #NUM! error.
* If @k <= 0 or @k is greater than the number of data items given LARGE returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LINEST function calculates the ``least squares'' line that best fit to your data in @known_y's. @known_x's contains the corresponding x's where y=mx+b.
LINEST returns an array having two columns and one row. The slope (m) of the regression line y=mx+b is given in the first column and the y-intercept (b) in the second.

If @stat is TRUE, extra statistical information will be returned. Extra statistical information is written bellow the regression line coefficients in the result array. Extra statistical information consists of four rows of data. In the first row the standard error values for the coefficients m1, (m2, ...), b are represented. The second row contains the square of R and the standard error for the y estimate. The third row contains the F-observed value and the degrees of freedom. The last row contains the regression sum of squares and the residual sum of squares.
* If @known_x's is omitted, an array {1, 2, 3, ...} is used.
* If @known_y's and @known_x's have unequal number of data points, LINEST returns #NUM! error.
* If @const is FALSE, the line will be forced to go through the origin, i.e., b will be zero. The default is TRUE.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGEST function applies the ``least squares'' method to fit an exponential curve of the form
y = b * m{1}^x{1} * m{2}^x{2}... to your data.

If @stat is TRUE, extra statistical information will be returned. Extra statistical information is written bellow the regression line coefficients in the result array. Extra statistical information consists of four rows of data. In the first row the standard error values for the coefficients m1, (m2, ...), b are represented. The second row contains the square of R and the standard error for the y estimate. The third row contains the F-observed value and the degrees of freedom. The last row contains the regression sum of squares and the residual sum of squares.
* If @known_x's is omitted, an array {1, 2, 3, ...} is used. LOGEST returns an array { m{n},m{n-1}, ...,m{1},b }.
* If @known_y's and @known_x's have unequal number of data points, LOGEST returns #NUM! error.
* If @const is FALSE, the line will be forced to go through (0,1),i.e., b will be one. The default is TRUE.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGFIT function applies the ``least squares'' method to fit the logarithmic equation
y = a + b * ln(sign * (x - c)) , sign = +1 or -1
to your data. The graph of the equation is a logarithmic curve moved horizontally by c and possibly mirrored across the y-axis (if sign = -1).
LOGFIT returns an array having five columns and one row. `Sign' is given in the first column, `a', `b', and `c' are given in columns 2 to 4. Column 5 holds the sum of squared residuals.
An error is returned when there are less than 3 different x's or y's, or when the shape of the point cloud is too different from a ``logarithmic'' one.
You can use the above formula
to compute unknown y's or x's, respectively.

Technically, this is non-linear fitting by trial-and-error. The accuracy of `c' is: width of x-range -> rounded to the next smaller (10^integer), times 0.000001. There might be cases in which the returned fit is not the best possible.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGINV function returns the inverse of the lognormal cumulative distribution. @p is the given probability corresponding to the normal distribution, @mean is the arithmetic mean of the distribution, and @stddev is the standard deviation of the distribution.
* If @p < 0 or @p > 1 or @stddev <= 0 LOGINV returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGISTIC returns the probability density p(x) at @x for a logistic distribution with scale parameter @a.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGNORMDIST function returns the lognormal distribution. @x is the value for which you want the distribution, @mean is the mean of the distribution, and @stddev is the standard deviation of the distribution.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOGREG function transforms your x's to z=ln(x) and applies the ``least squares'' method to fit the linear equation
to your y's and z's --- equivalent to fitting the equation
If @known_x's is omitted, an array {1, 2, 3, ...} is used. LOGREG returns an array having two columns and one row. m is given in the first column and b in the second.
If @known_y's and @known_x's have unequal number of data points, LOGREG returns #NUM! error.
If @const is FALSE, the curve will be forced to go through [1; 0], i.e., b will be zero. The default is TRUE.

If @stat is TRUE, extra statistical information will be returned which applies to the state AFTER transformation to z. Extra statistical information is written below m and b in the result array. Extra statistical information consists of four rows of data. In the first row the standard error values for the coefficients m, b are represented. The second row contains the square of R and the standard error for the y estimate. The third row contains the F-observed value and the degrees of freedom. The last row contains the regression sum of squares and the residual sum of squares.The default of @stat is FALSE.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MAX returns the value of the element of the values passed that has the largest value, with negative numbers considered smaller than positive numbers.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MAXA returns the largest value of the given arguments. Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers and strings 11.4, 17.3, "missing", 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MEDIAN returns the median of the given data set.
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.
* If even numbers are given MEDIAN returns the average of the two numbers in the middle.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: AVERAGE, COUNT, COUNTA, DAVERAGE, MODE, SSMEDIAN, SUM.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MIN returns the value of the element of the values passed that has the smallest value, with negative numbers considered smaller than positive numbers.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MINA returns the smallest value of the given arguments. Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers and strings 11.4, 17.3, "missing", 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MODE returns the most common number of the data set. If the data set has many most common numbers MODE returns the first one of them.
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.
* If the data set does not contain any duplicates MODE returns #N/A error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 11.4, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NEGBINOMDIST function returns the negative binomial distribution. @f is the number of failures, @t is the threshold number of successes, and @p is the probability of a success.
* If @f or @t is a non-integer it is truncated.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NORMDIST function returns the normal cumulative distribution. @x is the value for which you want the distribution, @mean is the mean of the distribution, @stddev is the standard deviation.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NORMINV function returns the inverse of the normal cumulative distribution. @p is the given probability corresponding to the normal distribution, @mean is the arithmetic mean of the distribution, and @stddev is the standard deviation of the distribution.
* If @p < 0 or @p > 1 or @stddev <= 0 NORMINV returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NORMSDIST function returns the standard normal cumulative distribution. @x is the value for which you want the distribution.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: NORMSINV function returns the inverse of the standard normal cumulative distribution. @p is the given probability corresponding to the normal distribution.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PARETO returns the probability density p(x) at @x for a Pareto distribution with exponent @a and scale @b.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PEARSON returns the Pearson correlation coefficient of two data sets.
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PERCENTILE function returns the 100*@k-th percentile of the given data points (that is, a number x such that a fraction @k of the data points are less than x).
* If @array is empty, PERCENTILE returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PERCENTRANK function returns the rank of a data point in a data set. @array is the range of numeric values, @x is the data point which you want to rank, and the optional @significance indentifies the number of significant digits for the returned value, truncating the remainder. If @significance is omitted, PERCENTRANK uses three digits.
* If @array contains no data points, PERCENTRANK returns #NUM! error.
* If @significance is less than one, PERCENTRANK returns #NUM! error.
* If @x exceeds the largest value or is less than the smallest value in @array, PERCENTRANK returns #NUM! error.
* If @x does not match any of the values in @array or @x matches more than once, PERCENTRANK interpolates the returned value.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: LARGE, MAX, MEDIAN, MIN, PERCENTILE, QUARTILE, SMALL.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PERMUT function returns the number of permutations. @n is the number of objects, @k is the number of objects in each permutation.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: POISSON function returns the Poisson distribution. @x is the number of events, @mean is the expected numeric value @cumulative describes whether to return the sum of the poisson function from 0 to @x.
* If @x is a non-integer it is truncated.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PROB function returns the probability that values in a range or an array are between two limits. If @upper_limit is not given, PROB returns the probability that values in @x_range are equal to @lower_limit.
* If the sum of the probabilities in @prob_range is not equal to 1 PROB returns #NUM! error.
* If any value in @prob_range is <=0 or > 1, PROB returns #NUM! error.
* If @x_range and @prob_range contain a different number of data entries, PROB returns #N/A error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: QUARTILE function returns the quartile of the given data points.
If @quart is equal to: QUARTILE returns:
* If @array is empty, QUARTILE returns #NUM! error.
* If @quart is not an integer, it is truncated.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: LARGE, MAX, MEDIAN, MIN, PERCENTILE, SMALL.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RANK returns the rank of a number in a list of numbers. @x is the number whose rank you want to find, @ref is the list of numbers, and @order specifies how to rank numbers. If @order is 0, numbers are ranked in descending order, otherwise numbers are ranked in ascending order.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RAYLEIGH returns the probability density p(x) at @x for a Rayleigh distribution with scale parameter @sigma.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RAYLEIGHTAIL returns the probability density p(x) at @x for a Rayleigh tail distribution with scale parameter @sigma and lower limit @a.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RSQ returns the square of the Pearson correlation coefficient of two data sets.
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: CORREL, COVAR, INTERCEPT, LINEST, LOGEST, PEARSON, SLOPE, STEYX, TREND.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SKEW returns an unbiased estimate for skewness of a distribution.
Note, that this is only meaningful if the underlying distribution really has a third moment. The skewness of a symmetric (e.g., normal) distribution is zero.
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.
* If less than three numbers are given, SKEW returns #DIV/0! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SKEWP returns the population skewness of a data set.
* Strings and empty cells are simply ignored.
* If less than two numbers are given, SKEWP returns #DIV/0! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SLOPE returns the slope of the linear regression line.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1, and the cells B1, B2, ... B5 23.2, 25.8, 29.9, 33.5, and 42.7. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SMALL returns the k-th smallest value in a data set.
* If data set is empty SMALL returns #NUM! error.
* If @k <= 0 or @k is greater than the number of data items given SMALL returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The SSMEDIAN function returns the median for grouped data as commonly determined in the social sciences. The data points given in @array are assumed to be the result of grouping data into intervals of length @interval
* If @interval is not given, SSMEDIAN uses 1.
* If @array is empty, SSMEDIAN returns #NUM! error.
* SSMEDIAN does not check whether the data points are at least @interval apart.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, A3 contain numbers 7, 8, 8. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: STANDARDIZE function returns a normalized value. @x is the number to be normalized, @mean is the mean of the distribution, @stddev is the standard deviation of the distribution.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: STDEV returns standard deviation of a set of numbers treating these numbers as members of a population.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: AVERAGE, DSTDEV, DSTDEVP, STDEVA, STDEVPA, VAR.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: STDEVA returns the standard deviation based on a sample. Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers and strings 11.4, 17.3, "missing", 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: STDEVP returns standard deviation of a set of numbers treating these numbers as members of a complete population.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: STDEVPA returns the standard deviation based on the entire population. Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers and strings 11.4, 17.3, "missing", 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: STEYX function returns the standard error of the predicted y-value for each x in the regression.
* If @known_y's and @known_x's are empty or have a different number of arguments then STEYX returns #N/A error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1, and the cells B1, B2, ... B5 23.2, 25.8, 29.9, 33.5, and 42.7. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SUBTOTAL function returns a subtotal of given list of arguments. @function_nbr is the number that specifies which function to use in calculating the subtotal.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 23, 27, 28, 33, and 39. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TDIST function returns the Student's t-distribution. @dof is the degree of freedom and @tails is 1 or 2 depending on whether you want one-tailed or two-tailed distribution.
* If @tails is neither 1 or 2 TDIST returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TINV function returns the inverse of the two-tailed Student's t-distribution.
* If @p < 0 or @p > 1 or @dof < 1 TINV returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TREND function estimates future values of a given data set using the ``least squares'' line that best fit to your data. @known_y's is the y-values where y=mx+b and @known_x's contains the corresponding x-values. @new_x's contains the x-values for which you want to estimate the y-values. If @const is FALSE, the line will be forced to go through the origin, i.e., b will be zero.
* If @known_x's is omitted, an array {1, 2, 3, ...} is used.
* If @new_x's is omitted, it is assumed to be the same as @known_x's.
* If @const is omitted, it is assumed to be TRUE.
* If @known_y's and @known_x's have unequal number of data points, TREND returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1, and the cells B1, B2, ... B5 23.2, 25.8, 29.9, 33.5, and 42.7. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TRIMMEAN returns the mean of the interior of a data set. @ref is the list of numbers whose mean you want to calculate and @fraction is the fraction of the data set excluded from the mean. For example, if @fraction=0.2 and the data set contains 40 numbers, 8 numbers are trimmed from the data set (40 x 0.2), 4 from the top and 4 from the bottom of the set.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TTEST function returns the probability of a Student's t-Test.

@array1 is the first data set and @array2 is the second data set. If @tails is one, TTEST uses the one-tailed distribution and if @tails is two, TTEST uses the two-tailed distribution. @type determines the kind of the test:
* If the data sets contain a different number of data points and the test is paired (@type one), TTEST returns the #N/A error.
* If @tails is not one or two, TTEST returns #NUM! error.
* If @type is any other than one, two, or three, TTEST returns #NUM! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1, and the cells B1, B2, ... B5 23.2, 25.8, 29.9, 33.5, and 42.7. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VAR estimates the variance of a sample of a population. To get the true variance of a complete population use VARP.
* VAR is also known as the N-1-variance. Under reasonable conditions, it is the maximum-likelihood estimator for the true variance.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VARA returns the variance based on a sample. Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers and strings 11.4, 17.3, "missing", 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VARP calculates the variance of a set of numbers where each number is a member of a population and the set is the entire population.
* VARP is also known as the N-variance.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: VARPA returns the variance based on the entire population. Numbers, text and logical values are included in the calculation too. If the cell contains text or the argument evaluates to FALSE, it is counted as value zero (0). If the argument evaluates to TRUE, it is counted as one (1). Note that empty cells are not counted.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers and strings 11.4, 17.3, "missing", 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: WEIBULL function returns the Weibull distribution. If the @cumulative boolean is true it will return:

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ZTEST returns the two-tailed probability of a z-test.
@ref is the data set and @x is the value to be tested.
* If @ref contains less than two data items ZTEST returns #DIV/0! error.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Let us assume that the cells A1, A2, ..., A5 contain numbers 11.4, 17.3, 21.3, 25.9, and 40.1. Then

refsect1.title: See also
refsect1.para: CONFIDENCE, NORMDIST, NORMINV, NORMSDIST, NORMSINV, STANDARDIZE.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CHAR returns the ASCII character represented by the number @x.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CLEAN removes any non-printable characters from @string.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CODE returns the ASCII number for the character @char.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: CONCATENATE returns the string obtained by concatenation of the given strings.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: EXACT returns true if @string1 is exactly equal to @string2 (this routine is case sensitive).

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIND returns position of @string1 in @string2 (case-sensitive), searching only from character @start onwards (assuming 1 if omitted).

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXED returns @num as a formatted string with @decimals numbers after the decimal point, omitting commas if requested by @no_commas.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LEFT returns the leftmost @num_chars characters or the left character if @num_chars is not specified.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LEN returns the length in characters of the string @string.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: LOWER returns a lower-case version of the string in @text.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: LOWER("J. F. Kennedy") equals "j. f. kennedy".

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: MID returns a substring from @string starting at @position for @length characters.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: PROPER returns @string with initial of each word capitalised.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: PROPER("j. f. kennedy") equals "J. F. Kennedy".

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: REPLACE returns @old with @new replacing @num characters from @start.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: RIGHT returns the rightmost @num_chars characters or the right character if @num_chars is not specified.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SEARCH returns the location of the @search_ string within @text. The search starts with the @start_num character of text @text. If @start_num is omitted, it is assumed to be one. The search is not case sensitive.

@search_string can contain wildcard characters (*) and question marks (?). A question mark matches any character and a wildcard matches any string including the empty string. If you want the actual wildcard or question mark to be found, use tilde (~) before the character.
* If @search_string is not found, SEARCH returns #VALUE! error.
* If @start_num is less than one or it is greater than the length of @text, SEARCH returns #VALUE! error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: SUBSTITUTE replaces @old with @new in @text. Substitutions are only applied to instance @num of @old in @text, otherwise every one is changed.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: T returns @value if and only if it is text, otherwise a blank string.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TEXT returns @value as a string with the specified format.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TRIM returns @text with only single spaces between words.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: TRIM(" a bbb cc") equals "a bbb cc".

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: UNICHAR returns the unicode character represented by the number @x.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: UNICHAR(8232) equals an carriage return error.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: UNICODE returns the unicode number for the character @char.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: UPPER returns a upper-case version of the string in @text.
